SimpleTask List App

my first JavaScript DOM Project

  • 29 July 2020
  • View GitHub
  • Live Version

About the Project

About a month ago I started learing JavaScript for the first time. I was initially a little intimidated by it as knowing when to move on to learning it can be quite difficult.

None the less after watching Kyle Simpsons Introduction to JavaScript over on Front End Masters I decided get started as I know learning JavaScript is like building the pyramids...by yourself...brick by brick.

It was then that I enrolled in the Front End Career path at Scrimba and bought Brad Traversy's JavaScript courses over on Udemy and got to work.

Anyways I've just learnt about the DOM, which is awesome, and needed a small project to practice on. So, like all new coders I see, doing a task list style app is a fun place to start.

Currently and quite sadly, only the Monday task list works as I'm yet to have enough knowledge on seperating the lists etc, adding data attributes and being able to uniquely add them to local storage BUT I am proud of my first little project for now and will for sure comeback to it in the future.

My Goal

My goal was simple. Create ONE (someday multiple) task list that works! This list needed to have:

  • The ability to add, complete and remove tasks.
  • For these tasks to be saved to or removed from local storage.
  • And for the limit of tasks to be 10.

Note: I also got carried away and added a theme selector!? ðŸ˜€

Features & Tech

It's not Todoist, Trello or anything fancy but I learnt a lot and used what I already know about HTML, CSS and Bootstrap to create something a little more apealing that your usual task list.

Features & Tech

  • HTML
  • CSS
  • BootStrap
  • JavaScript DOM Manipulation
  • JavaScript Local Storage
  • Font Awesome
  • Google Fonts

What I Learnt

Again, after spending time learning theory, actually trying to build something similar from scratch took forever (14 hours) but I learnt so much! I encountered A LOT of bugs initially, but by taking things line by line and using the Developer Console effectively, I managed to get it working!

I think one of the hardest things about first starting JavaScript is how many different ways there is to accomplish a task and although my way I'm sure is not optimal, it worked and I'm happy with how much I learnt.

What I'd Improve

Aw, this is simple! Have all the lists works!! ðŸ˜” I'm sure it is something basic I am overlooking but after a whole day of trying, I decided to continue learning and building other small projects for now.

Conclusion

This was a fun project! Writing code that actually works and that makes a website interactive is a really cool feeling!

It's safe to say I'm pretty addicted to JavaScript and cannot wait to learn more.
